DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Cancer Mixed In Situ Histology Extent Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description and numeric percentage of the extent of the mixed or indeterminate in situ component associated with invasive cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Invasive Malignant Neoplasm Mixed In Situ Histology
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_Involving or composed of different kinds._in the natural or normal place, confined to the site of origin without invasion of neighboring tissues. (On-line Medical Dictionary)_The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Involving or composed of different kinds.:in the natural or normal place, confined to the site of origin without invasion of neighboring tissues. (On-line Medical Dictionary):The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: Involving or composed of different kinds.
In the natural or normal place, confined to the site of origin without invasion of neighboring tissues.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.
